Security forces pushed protesting workers from the SN-SOSUCO factory workers, arresting 26. Several injuries on both sides.
A Darfuri refugee was found dead outside of the Iridimi camp with "markings of beatings and torture all over his body."

Police used gunfire and tear gas to remove striking employees from the premises of the SN-SOSUCU sugar factory. The protesters returned and forced through the police line. A fire damaged the factory and injuries were reported on both sides.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Associated Press; Deutsche Welle; Radio France Internationale; Medecins Sans Frontieres
notes: Three or four suicide attacks at markets on Loulou Fou or Koulfoua island killed at least 27 people including the attackers and injured more than 80.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
notes: Armed men attacked a truck carrying migrants, killing four and wounding six.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Nigerian Tribune
notes: Boko Haram killed four, injured two, and burned about 50 homes in a cross-border raid.

actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
source: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English
notes: Ansar Dine launched a mortar attack on the MINUSMA base in Kidal, killing two peacekeepers and one civilian contractor and injuring at least 14.
Suspected jihadists with rocket launchers and automatic rifles attacked an armored cash truck near the Inata gold mine, killing the driver and wounding another. Police fought off the attackers.
Unidentified gunmen attacked the convey of a mining company, killing a driver and exchanging fire with security guards before fleeing.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Gogone, killing 18 including the local imam, and burning 70 houses; villagers fought back with bows and arrows. 11 were injured and a child disappeared.

actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
source: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse
notes: UN vehicle hit an explosive device about 25 km from Timbuktu, killing one civilian staff member.

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of France; Military Forces of the United States
source: ORTM TV; Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse; Aljazeera
notes: Mali special forces with support from French and US military responded to the hostage taking at the Radisson Blu hotel, killing at least two assailants as they released the remaining hostages. At least two military were injured in the fight against the newly formed Al Mourabitoun Battalion group, while FLM also claims responsibility for the attack.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse; Aljazeera
notes: The newly formed Al Mourabitoun Battalion group attacked the Radisson Blu hotel, taking more than 170 hostages and killing at least 19 civilians. FLM also claims responsibility.
One soldier was killed an another injured when FLM attacked their post in Djenne. The attacked was perhaps retaliation for the arrest of an FLM leader the previous day.
Arrests: Military forces arrested FLM leader Allaye Bocari Dia

source: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
notes: Opposition supporters and police clashed around the airport as opposition presidential candidate Hama Amadou arrived by plane and was immdiately arrested. Several rioters were also arrested and a child was reportedly killed by a motorcycle.
Staff of the International Engineering Institute protested the recent firings of teachers by blocking roads into campus.

assoc_actor_1: CCVC: National Coalition against High Cost of Living, Corruption, Fraud and Impunity and for Liberty
notes: Protesters marched against "dysfunctional" city services, including water cuts and poorly run hospitals.
An explosive device was set off at the entrance of a building for an NGO in Menaka, causing material damage.
Employees of SN-SOSUCO went on strike and started camping out in front of the factory.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
notes: Two female suicide bombers killed themselves and at least two civilians in an attack attributed to Boko Haram on Ngouboua village. 14 were injured. Days later, the government imposed a state of emergency, limiting movement and authorizing searches.
Residents of the Toudweogo neighborhood in Ouagadougou held a spontaneous protests against poor road conditions, blocking the road.

assoc_actor_1: F-SYNTER: Federation of National Unions of Workers in Education and Research
notes: Union members held a sit-in to demand better working conditions at the International Institute for Water and Environmental Engineering (2iE).
Residents in the Dapoya neighborhood of Ouagadougou protested against the closing of a health center.
Officers of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs held a sit-in to demand administrative changes.
The Niger army launched airstrikes against Boko Haram near the village of Dagaya. Casualty figures unknown, while 20 Boko Haram militants were arrested.
Public university students marched as part of a strike against administrative policies.
Suspected jihadists opened fire on a canoe, injuring one, presumably in response to the militarys arrest of 4 suspected jihadists that day.
A military convoy drove over a mine and then exchanged fire with Boko Haram. One soldier died.

Three Boko Haram died and 11 civilians were wounded as soldiers repelled an attempted suicide bombing at the Bougama military post near Bamou village on Lake Chad. Simultaneously soldiers killed 11 Boko Haram members during an attempted suicide attack on the Kaika army post. Two soldiers were also killed.
Thousands protested in favor of "credible elections"

source: Le Depeches de Brazzaville; Radio France Internationale; Maghreb Emergent
notes: The military killed 7 FLM jihadists and injured 10 in clashes near the Tiebanda forest near the border with Burkina Faso as part of the new military operation "Seno".
Protests against poor municipal management caused the local Prefect official to flee town.
Boko Haram attacked the Ala village just across the border from Nigeria in the Diffa region, killing 13 and injuring 3 while burning buildings.

actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
notes: A landmine exploded, kililng three civilians and wounding two peacekeepers near Tessalit.
Artisans held a sit-in to demand better conditions in the artisinal village.

assoc_actor_1: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
notes: Authorities claim members of the IRA kidnapped and tortured a young girl. IRA leaders deny involvement.

source: Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse - English
notes: A suicide attacker killed himself and two soldiers on the outskirts of Diffa. The military killed three other would-be bombers at the scene.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
notes: Violent clashes between police and students protesting for better study conditions left at least seven injured and led to 79 arrests. Demonstrators threw stones and set fires, while police used tear gas.
Demonstrators protested in front of the Health Ministry against "the deteriorating health situation"
Insurgents conducted a raid and opened fire in the city, killing two civilians as they fled.

actor1: CMA: Coordination of Movements of the Azawad
actor2: GATIA: Imghad Tuareg and Allies Self-Defense Group

Arrests: Police arrested 62 women for wearing full veils in public and also arrested 8 suspected "jihadis" in the first major arrests since the veil ban.

Ansar Dine leader Esse Ag Warakoule was killed during the week of October 11th in a French military operation in northern Mali, near the Algerian border. One of his children was also killed in the operation.

Strikes: Salafist prisoners went on a hunger strike, demanding dialogue with the authorities. On 11 January 30 Islamist prisoners re-launched a hunger strike to denounce punitive measures in the jail. After ten weeks, the strike was suspended when prison administration agreed to some of their demands.

Security Measures: The council of ministers placed the region of Diffa under a state of emergency for two weeks. This allows authorities to impose curfews and limit movement as part of the fight against Boko Haram.

Students encircled and overtook the administrative building of the General Directorate of the National Center of Academic Affairs, demanding the dismissal of the Director General and retraction of previous vandalism charges.
Three French special forces were injured in a landmine blast somewhere in "the north".

assoc_actor_2: Civilians (Mali); MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
source: Agence France Presse - English; Xinhua General News Service
notes: After a civilian car hit a landmine 40-100km from Gao, militants armed with rocket launders and machine guns attacked their vehicles being guarded by the military. MINUSMA sent two vehicles which were then set on fire. A total of 6 were killed.

Students blocked routes to the university in Bobo-Dioulasso and overtook canteens on campus, demanding the reopening of certain buildings, reductions in rent, increased bus access, and improvements in food service.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Associated Press International; Xinhua General News Service
notes: Suicide bombers, including 3 women and 2 children likely affiliated with Boko Haram, attacked a fish market and IDP camps, killing 47 and injuring dozens.

source: Xinhua News Agency - French; Agence France Presse
notes: Armed men attacked the Camp I gendarmerie in Bamako, allowing 9 prisoners to escape, including 8 who were connected to the 2012 coup.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale; Xinhua General News Service
notes: Three police were killed in a raid on their barracks carried out by at least 30 attackers - perhaps jihadists" connected to a simultaneous attack in the Mopti region of Mali, or troops associated with a recent failed coup in Burkina Faso. 1 assailant and 1 civilian were also killed.

source: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse; Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
notes: "Jihadists" with suspected ties to FLM killed injured several and killed 3, including an elected official.
Dozens of protesters, mostly youth, held a sit in against the Ministry of Healths inaction against a recent fever epidemic.

source: Deutsche Welle; Agence France Presse - English
notes: Boko Haram carried out a pre-dawn strike near Lake Chad, killing 11 soldiers and wounding several. 17 Boko Haram militants also died in the clashes.
One person was killed and four kidnapped in a village in the Gao region when Tuareg separatists targeted family members of Tuaregs aligned with the government.
Detonation: Three Boko Haram militants died when a bomb they were transporting exploded.
Dozens of workers from the Bissa Gold mining company held a sit-in to demand payment of September salaries.

source: Associated Press International; Vanguard website; Agence France Presse
notes: At least one suicide bombing took place, perhaps two, when police confronted suspected members of Boko Haram, who then detonated explosives. A policeman, 4 militants, and at least 5 civilians died.
Students smashed windows and surrounded cars while protesting at Kossodo University, demanding that classes resume since the coup events of September have finished.
On their way to protect the village of Baroua, troops were ambushed by Boko Haram who killed 2 and wounded 7.

Non-violent activity: Soldiers were seen throughout the Ouaga 2000 district of Ouagadougou looking for members of the Presidential Security Unit. Marksmen were seen in positions around the Presidential Security barracks.

assoc_actor_1: UST: Union of Chadian Trade Unions
notes: Strikes: Trade unions started a three day strike nationwide, claiming there is a delay in paments of wages, grants, pensions, and scholarships.

Boko Haram cross from Nigeria into Komadougou Yobe and kill 15 civilians.

actor1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit

Rioters burned tries in the street in protest of the draft agreement between military and coup leaders, which proposed to allow loyalists of former President Compoare and members of former ruling party to participate in elections.

Youth and other protesters blocked the western entrance to Ouagadougou, setting fire to tires to put pressure on coup leaders.
FLM attacked the village of Bi/Nangabara near the border with Burkina Faso, killing two policemen and two civilians.
The homes of two former Compaore allies (Simon Compaore and Salif Diallo) were ransacked by anti-coup rioters.
Anti-coup protesters continued to march in Bobo-Dioulasso, ignoring the newly imposed curfew.

Protesters set up barricades and lowered government flags in reaction to a recent coup.

Strikes: 17 trade unions call general strike until presidential guard behind the coup is dissolved.

actor1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit

actor1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit

The hostages were released late the following day and the president security unit announced it had taken control of the country in a coup. They named themselves the National Council for Democracy and declared General Gilbert Diendere their leader. The closed land and air borders for 24 hours and put a curfew in effect.

actor1: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (2014-2015) Presidential Security Unit
source: Media Foundation for West Africa; Xinhua General News Service
notes: Members of the Presidential Security Unit forced radio stations to shut down throughout the capital as they executed a coup at the Presidential Palace. Some journalists were also beaten on the streets as they tried to cover the situation.
Dozens protested to decry human rights violations against Haratine women working in Saudi Arabia.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAFI: National Union of Finance Agents
notes: Workers from the Ministry of Finance held a sit-in as part of an ongoing strike. Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas.

source: Xinhua General News Service; Daily Trust (Abuja); Radio France Internationale
notes: At least one police officer was killed and another injured when armed men on a motorcycle opened fire at a security post. They also burned the office of the village administrator and two vehicles. The attackers are suspected members of the Front for the Liberation of Macina.

actor2: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
notes: Two UN peacekeepers were injured in an ambush on the Gao-Anefis Road, about 15km from Gao
Hundreds of protesters marched against suspected fraud by public servants.

notes: Workers from the Ministry of Finance went on strike and held a sit-in in front of the Ministry.
Protesters were arrested while holding a sit-in against the Nantou Mining company.
Militants killed one soldier and wounded seven in an ambush near Diafarabe.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Agence Malienne de Presse
notes: Two soldiers were killed in a pre-dawn attack against an army checkpoint outside Timbuktu.
Several were arrested while protesting outside fo the Saudi embassy, claiming ill treatment of Mauritanian Harati women in Saudi Arabia.
Employees of SN SOSUCO demonstrated against a recent deal to import sugar from Brazil. They blocked the roads that lead from Banforo to Bobo-Dioulasso and Orodara.
Youth held a sit-in against the Nantou Mining company.
An imam led a protest against "confiscation" of a public square in front of a mosque and was arrested.
Two suspected Boko Haram members blew themselves up on Lake Chad while being pursued by the Chadian military.
Soldiers from military unit 7 attacked the security center in the Brakna region "to avenge a comrade" who had been beaten by members of Brigade 4. A number of those soldiers were arrested.
Unidentified individuals attacked and seriously injured a security guard at the independent Radio Manegmoogo in Pissila. Then they set fire to the building.
Some 10 people have been killed in clashes between rival tribes (Toubou and Zaghawa) near a gold mine.

Around 200 people peacefully protested against heavy taxation, and police arrested 17 people for "inciting revolt", including a village chief and a radio director.

Sit-ins took place in Nouakchott in tandem with those in the east protesting government inaction after Malian forces killed a merchant.

Jihadists linked with the new group Macina Liberation Front killed a village imam who refused their repeated attempts to recruit him.

source: Xinhua General News Service; Agence France Presse - English
notes: Two armed men opened fired at police officers at a roundabout in Bamako, injuring at least one police officer and one civilian.

source: Xinhua News Agency - French; Maghreb Emergent
notes: 3 soldiers were killed and 4 injured when their vehicle hit an explosive device near Diabozo. The attack was claimed by El Mourabitoun.
The day after a battle with residents of Gaberi, unidentified gunmen returned and attacked again, leaving 10 dead.
Gunmen on motorbikes attacked the village of Gaberi and were fought off by residents. One attacker was killed.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Deutsche Welle; Al Jazeera; Agence France Presse - English
notes: Gunmen attacked a Malian military site and were repelled, so they seiged a hotel in Sevare, taking several hostages. In the course of the siege, at least 12 were killed including 5 militants, five soldiers and 2 foreign civilians, including one UN employee (civilian deaths coded separately). El Mourabitoun claimed responsibility and authorities believe the newly formed FLM may also be involved.

source: Al Jazeera; Agence France Presse - English
notes: Gunmen seize a hotel and several hostages in a siege in Sevare, Mopti. In the course of the siege, at least 12 were killed including 5 militants; five soldiers and 2 foreign civilians, including one UN employee (battle deaths coded separately). El Mourabitoun claimed responsibility and authorities believe the newly formed FLM may also be involved.
In a battle between Boko Haram and the Chadian military near Tchoukou Telia on Lake Chad, 7 Islamists were killed and 2 soldiers were injured.

actor1: AQIM: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
source: ORTM TV; Agence France Presse - English

Two Malian soldiers were killed and at least four injured when their convoy was ambushed on the road between Nampala and Diabaly. The military responded and seized a number of light weapons.

Protesters from Falangoutou, Gorom-Gorom, Essakane and Markoye came together to demonstrate against the employment practices of the IAMGOLD mining company. At least 28 were arrested for vandalism and destruction of property.

notes: 100 IRA anti-slavery protesters in Nouakchott demand release of their leader and one of his aides who were arrested. Police used tear gas and batons to disperse protesters, injuring 6. 23 arrested.

Clashes between military and Boko Haram 20kms south of Baga Sola, Lake Chad. Boko Haram reportedly abducted an unknown number of soldiers. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).

Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Medi Koura, during a search operation for Boko Haram hiding on the lakes islands. At time of fighting, reported that 6 Boko Haram killed, 15 wounded. One soldier killed. Later, Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia). In Medi Koura, Boko Haram reported to have kidnapped women and children.

Clashes between military and Boko Haram in Blarigi Island on Lake Chad. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).

In Ouaregou, in the Beguedo district, a dispute between two Muslim brotherhoods degenerated into clashes, resulting in many injuries and material damage.
Clashes between Fulani and Nupe youth in Kakakpangi village in Katchan Katchan area. 2 killed. Police deployed to the area.

assoc_actor_1: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)
notes: A Malian armed forces convoy containing MINUSMA vehicles was ambushed by suspected Islamist militias who used IEDs. 1 Malian soldier was wounded, while 1 Malian military vehicles and 2 MINUSMA vehicles were damaged.
6 people were killed by Fulani in Mondoro allegedly connected to a continuation of an ongoing dispute between Fulani and Dogono farmers.
7 civilians were killed by unidentified gunmen riding on a motorcycle near the border with Burkina Faso in the Kobou area.
19 Boko Haram fighters and 1 Chadian soldier were killed in an attack on a military position in Konguia (lat/longs not available).
1 villager was killed and 3 others injured in a suspected Boko Haram raid on Midi on the banks of Lake Chad.

source: Xinhua News Agency - French; Agence France Presse -- English
notes: As many as 10 residents of Gamgara, in the Bosso area, were killed in an attack by Boko Haram, while several others were seriously injured.

Boko Haram fighters attacked Tetewa Island on Lake Chad, near the border with Nigeria. Chad army reported 117 Boko Haram militants killed and 2 soldiers killed in clashes the last two weeks of July in the Lakes region (30 fatalities coded for July 13 clashes in Bol, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Medi Koura, 30 coded for July 25 clashes in Blarigi, and 29 coded for July 27 clashes in Telia).

3 Boko Haram fighters and 1 officer of the Nigerien national guard were killed in an attack on the civilian prison in Diffa. The officer was killed when one of the attackers detonated an explosive belt, while another guard was injured.

source: Xinhua General News Service; Radio France Internationale; Jeune Afrique
notes: A Boko Haram suicide bomb attack killed 15 and wounded at least 74 others near the central market in NDjamena.

15 people were killed, including one gendarme, and 80 injured in a suicide attack at the entrance of a central market in Ndjamena. The suicide bomber was allegedly wearing a burqa and detonated the bomb when a municipal police officer and paramilitary official stopped the bomber to search him. The attack was claimed by Boko Haram.

A demonstration was taken out by activists of the 25 February movement against an alleged rape by a "road security man". 2 of the activists were arrested during the protest (specific location not given).

source: Agence France Presse - English; Agence France Presse
notes: Boko Haram slit the throats of five civilians during a targeted attack against workers from the Diffa area who were working near Bosso.

After a man was taken into police custody for his involvement in an altercation at a market, an angry mob attacked the police station, breaking windows and taking the man into their custody. The crowd beat the man until he was in serious condition and the authorities were able to regain custody.

notes: Hundreds of anti-slavery activists held a sit-in in front of the National Assembly, protesting the detention of two activists.
Boko Haram attacked the village of Memorom on Lake Chad, killing at least 3 and wounding around 12.

source: Agence France Presse - English; Associated Press International

source: Xinhua General News Service; Radio France Internationale

Boko Haram killed five people and injured four others in an attack on a town near Bosso. The militants used guns and set fire to victims, homes, and vehicles as well as the central market.

Two men tried to detonate suicide bombs outside the central police station but were intercepted and arrested.

source: Leadership (Abuja); Associated Press International; Deutsche Welle; Xinhua General News Service

Protesters came to the Korgho mine 20 km from Gaoua and asked miners to leave, which led to an altercation between the two groups causing at least 8 injuries and property damage. Police arrested some of the perpetrators.

source: Associated Press International; Agence France Presse - English; Radio France Internationale
notes: Dozens of Islamist militants on motorcycles attacked security forces in Misseni, killing at least one policeman and wounding two. They raised the flag of Ansar Dine before escaping, as the Malian army sent backup forces. At least two members of the Dawa Islamist sect with suspected ties to Ansar Dine were later arrested in connection with the incident.
Dozens of former employees of the french company PIZZORNO protested to demand payments.
A group from Guinea "stormed" the Malian village of Sanafara to carry out illegal gold mining and exchanged fire with Malian genderames for about four hours.
Thousands protested on the streets of Niamey against poor government management, including electrical outages.
A civilian was reportedly killed by an armed group about 30km north of Timbuktu.
A civilian was killed by armed men traveling in a vehicle near the town of Goundam.
A civilian was kidnapped and shot dead. The CMA claims that the victim was targeted by pro-government groups for his support of their rebellion.
Inhabitants from the Outourou and Negueni villages clashed over the proposed construction of a middle school, leaving 3 dead and 20 injured. All of the homes in Outourou were burned.

Dozens protested in conjunction with the arrival of President Abdelaziz to the Dar al-Barak area. At least four were arrested when the security forces dispersed them.

assoc_actor_1: FMDH: Moroccan Forum for Democracy and Human Rights
notes: Members of the executive office of the Moroccan Forum for Democracy and Human Rights held a sit-in at the UNHCR in Nouakchott, calling for them to address issues with the saharaoui camps in Algeria, particularly the expulsion of activist Mustapha Salma to Mauritania.
Workers at the Inata Mine went on strike from Dec 4 - 12, illegally occupying the mine to prevent access.

3 Malian civilians from the same family were kidnapped by armed men near Menaka. They are believed to have been taken by MUJAO, as other attacks have taken place in the same area carried out by MUJAO.

assoc_actor_1: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
notes: Dozens of IRA supporters conducted a sit-in ouside the Ministry of Justice to demand the release of imprisoned activists.

actor1: MINUSMA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali (2013-)

Opposition parties and activists boycotted the national celebrations for the 24th anniversary of President Idriss Deby Itnos accession to power.
Thousands of Chadiens from multiple faiths conducted a public group prayer for peace and unity. Local and foreign government officials also participated, along with civil society organizations.
Student teachers from the Institutde of Sciences protested for the reinstatement of an expelled classmate.

source: Agence France Presse; Associated Press; Radio France Internationale; PANAPRESS
notes: Two soldiers killed and four or more wounded in a convoy providing security to a government minister when they drove over a landmine.

source: BBC; Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse

French forces have carried out 5 days of air operations, including airstrikes, over the Amettetai valleys in northern Mali. Four arms caches were destroyed and training camps were targeted. Casualties were not reported.
Students at the University of Nouakchott Faculty of Medicine peacefully protested but were stopped by police. A number were of students were injured when a car ran them over.
In Aguelhok and Kidal, suspected al-Qaeda-linked rebels kidnapped 10 children and killed 2 others who tried to escape.
In Aguelhok and Kidal, suspected al-Qaeda-linked rebels kidnapped 10 children and killed 2 others who tried to escape.
Detonation: A suicide bomber blew himself up in a market, causing no casualties or major property damage. No group claimed the attack.
2 Tuaregs who had disappeared earlier in November on the border with Algeria were found dead near Kidal bound in a mat and a blanket. It is not clear who killed them.

assoc_actor_1: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
source: Sahara Media news agency website; BBC
notes: Anti-slavery group members protested outside the Palace of Justice in Rosso, demanding the release of eight of their leaders.

actor1: MUJAO: Movement for Unity and Jihad in West Africa
source: Xinhua News - French; Radio France Internationale; Agence France Presse
notes: "Armed men [allegedly militants] from northern Mali, aboard motorcycles, led an attack on Banibangou... killing a Nigerian policeman" and injuring two more during a two hour gunfight. The attack was claimed by MUJAO, and at least 1 of their fighters was killed and an unspecified number injured (they took the bodies with them).

source: Associated Press; Agence France Presse; Deutsche Welle (Bonn)
notes: Non-violent activity: Diplomat Michel Kafanda sworn in as transitional president, selected by a special committee chosing between 5 candidates to lead the country until elections next November. Zida, the army officer who took power after the fall of the president last month, was named Prime Minister, ensuring the military keeps a grip on the government during the transition.
2 youths were kidnapped from a convoy traveling from Algeria to Gao. They were taken by armed men near Anefis. Reports disagree about motives for the kidnapping.
2 youths on a motorcycle opened fire on a bar, killing a young man and injuring 6 civilians, 4 seriously. The attackers are believed to have been Islamist militants.
Strikes: All 220 agents of Niameys municipal police force were dismissed by order of the mayor following their attempted strikes.

source: Cameroon Tribune; Reuters Africa; Business Monitor Online; Africa Review; Agence France Presse
notes: Agreement: A framework for a transitional govt was unanimously accepted by political, religious, civil society and military leaders, effectively reopening government and resolving the recent coup until new elections are held.

Municipal police in Niamey have begun a 48-hour strike without minimum service to demand better working and living conditions. The strike was violently repressed by security forces with municipal officials and dozens of other injured.

assoc_actor_1: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
notes: For a second day, anti-slavery activists protested the arrests of IRA leaders and police responded with tear gas.

assoc_actor_1: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement

source: Xinhua News - French; Radio France Internationale

Youth attacked a filling station and petrol tanker during demonstrations, and security agents intervenced and chased the demonstrators.
Youth attacked state-owned vehicles during protests, and security agents intervened and chased the demonstrators.
Teachers led strikes and demonstrations and security agents responded with live ammunition that injured two people.

10 people were killed and 13 injured in a confrontation between farmers and herders in the area of Birnin Nkoni.

source: Xinhua News - French; Agence France Presse

Prisoners protested, police forces fired shots in the air. Reports of one death and others injured.
Students held a sit-in to protest the schools unfulfilled promises to improve housing and funding.
Protests over fuel shortage.
The Malian military has allegedly besieged the town of Bira near Timbuktu.

notes: Protesters gather at Radio Nationale du Burkina Faso (RTB) to hear Saran Sereme of the PDC: Parti pour le developpment et le changement. Military forces fire gunshots and teargas to disperse crowd before Sereme speaks. Military take control of RTB building. One person dead.

2 soldiers were killed and at least 4 other wounded by a roadside explosive device near the town of Almoustrate.
Bissa Gold mining company looted on Nov. 1.
Reports of looting along Independence Avenue in Ouagadougou on Oct. 31.

source: Agence France Presse; Radio France Internationale; Xinhua
notes: Tens of thousands of protesters gather in front of the National Assembly on Friday morning demanding Compaores resignation and calling for former defense minister Kouame Lougue to take power. Leader of opposition Zephyrinus Diabre urges crowds to maintain pressure by occupying public space.
Several hundred rioters attacked the governors home in Banfora, using machetes, clubs, and stones.
Looting of industrial and financial institutions in Bobo-Dioulasso.
Watam Language Kaizer plant in Kossodo in northeastern Ouagadougou looted on Oct. 31. Injuries reported.

Coup/Military takeover: President Compaore steps down as president. General Traore assumes position as acting Head of State (replaced by Gen. Zida on Nov. 1), creates a transitional government body for next 12 months, and announces elections will take place within 90 days.

assoc_actor_1: IRA: The Initiative for the Resurgence of Abolitionist Movement
notes: Anti-slavery activists were arrested for protesting in mosques for "disturbing prayer, inciting hatred and rebellion, and aggression against security forces"

actor2: Military Forces of Burkina Faso (1987-2014) Presidential Security Unit

Several hundred rioters attacked Radiodiffusion Television du Burkina building. State radio and TV ceased operation.
Rioting at Watam Language Kaizer plant in Kossodo in northeastern Ouagadougou on Oct. 30.

source: Agence France Presse; Deutsche Welle; Le Pays; BBC; The Guardian (Lagos); Associated Press
notes: Tens of thousands rioted and burned the Assemblee Nationale du Burkina Faso, and set fire to cars outside. Rioters wanted to stop parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit. President Compaore declares state of emergency; cancels the declaration a few hours later. Reports of 30 dead and 100 wounded. Later reports clarify a total of 24 deaths, around 650 wounded, and 265 infringements during the uprising.
Rioters burned several buildings in Bobo-Dioulasso, including the town hall and the residences of several borough mayors. Reports of 2 dead and 6 wounded.

source: Deutsche Welle; Fasozine; Radio France Internationale
notes: Riots throughout Ouagadougou; looting, burning homes of government officials, including mayor of Ouagadougou, Marin Casimir Ilbouda. One rioter killed by the police while attacking the home of President Comparoes brother, Francois Compaore.

assoc_actor_2: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
notes: Rioters burn headquarters of ruling party CDP: Congress for Democracy and Change. Also attacked and burned the homes of government officials in Ouahigouya, including those of Yacouba Barry, Salif Diallo, and mayor Gilbert Noel Ouedraogo. Police threw tear gas. One body found in Ouedraogos home after the fire. 3 deaths total reported.

Protesters gather at army headquarters at 7pm on Oct. 30, as Army General Honore Traore announces dissolution of government, calls off vote on constitutional amendment to two-term limit, and imposes a curfew.
Protests in Borfora on Oct. 30 to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.
Protests in Dori on Oct. 30 to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.
Protests in Fada NGourma on Oct. 30 to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.
Protests in Koudougou on Oct. 30, to prevent parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.

French forces engaged in a fight against a large "armed militant group" in the Tigharghar mountains overnight (Oct.29-30). 1 special forces member was killed and 2 other wounded. 24 militants were killed and 2 captured out of 30. A number of vehicle swere destroyed while arms and bomb-making materials were seized.
Trade unions and civil society go on strike and march in streets in Banfora to demand better costs of living and school accessibility.
Trade unions and civil society go on strike and march in streets in Dedougou to demand better costs of living and school accessibility.
Protesters and trade unions go on strike and march in the streets of Ouagadougou to demand better costs of living and school accessibility.
Trade unions and civil society go on strike and march in streets of Bobo-Dioulasso to demand better costs of living and school accessibility. Riots break out.
Rioters protested in Bobo-Dioulasso on Oct. 28 and destroyed a statute of Blaise Compaore. Police fired tear gas.
Hundreds of protesters in the streets in Banfora on Oct. 28 to protest the upcoming parliamentary vote. No reports of security forces present.
Hundreds of protesters in the streets in Dedougou on Oct. 28 to protest the upcoming parliamentary vote.

source: Reuters; Institute of Security Studies; Sidwaya
notes: Thousands of rioters in the streets of Ouagadougou on Oct. 28. Rioters burned tires and threw rocks. Police fired tear gas and water cannons. Riots trying to stop parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit.

source: Xinhua News - French; Associated Press; Radio France Internationale

Unidentified gunmen attacked a prison in Ouallam, which held both many Tuareg separatists and MUJAO prisoners, and released 58 people.

source: Xinhua News - French; Radio France Internationale
notes: Several unidentified gunmen (allegedly militants who shouted "God is Greatest" during their attacks) on motorcycles attacked the multiple locations in the locality of Ouallam.Unidentified gunmen attacked a patrol of the security services in the locality of Zaramou Darey. 2 national guard members and 2 security forces members were killed.

source: Xinhua News - French; United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees; Radio France Internationale
notes: Several unidentified gunmen (allegedly militants who shouted "God is Greatest" during their attacks) on motorcycles attacked the multiple locations in the locality of Ouallam. Unidentified gunmen attacked a Malian refugee camp in the locality of Mangaize, and burned the camps police station, killing at least 5 policemen, 1 civilian, and wounding 4 refugees. 3 attackers were also killed, and 4 others captured.

actor1: CMA: Coordination of Movements of the Azawad

Protests in streets of Bobo-Dioulasso on Oct. 27. To keep parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit. Part of a call for civil disobedience by political opposition leader Zephyrinus Diabre.

Protests in streets of Ouagadougou on Oct. 27. To keep parliament from voting on a constitutional amendment to the presidential two-term limit. Part of a call for civil disobedience by political opposition leader Zephyrinus Diabre.

Teachers sit-in at the Governorate of Hauts-Bassins to protest education policies.

Rioters used tree trunks and ropes to barricade National Highway 3 on the morning of Oct. 23, preventing all vehicles from leaving Ouagadougou. Riots were in reaction to governments announcement of a draft bill to amend the two-term presidential limit.

The French military has announced it will be establishing a forward base in Madama alongside the government of Niger to intensify its operations against militants in northern Mali and cut off their supply routes. About 50 French soldiers will be deployed, and it should be operations "within the coming weeks".

Crowds gathering in Ouagadougou on Oct. 21 to protest the governments intention to submit a draft law to amend the term-term presidential limit (which would allow President Compaore to stand for re-election in 2015).
Traders closed their shops and marched in the streets to demand the speedy construction of the central market in Dedougou.

Teachers hold sit-ins across the country to demand better conditions for education, including a stopping the continuum process for pre-schoolers, and adopting special status and housing allowance for education workers. Sit-ins nationwide on October 8, 9 and 10.

Teachers marched in Ougadougou on World Teachers Day, Oct. 8, demanding that the Minister for Secondary and Higher Education Moussa Ouattara stop the continuum system because there are not enough classrooms to accommodate students. Protest coincided with sit-ins across the country on October 8, 9 and 10.

assoc_actor_1: CSRD: Supreme Council for the Restoration of Democracy
notes: A military junta calling itself the Supreme Council for the Restoration of Democracy seized power; ousting President Tandja. Fatalities: 10 people. It was not stated which side of the violence the fatalities were on.

notes: Protesters demonstrated against President Tanja giving himself more power through the constitution.
